references: For the semi-supervised node classification task on subgraphs of hypergraphs, we use four hypergraph datasets provided by the DHG (DeepHypergraph) library, as shown in Table 1. These include the CoraCA from (Yadati et al. 2019) and DBLP4k from (Sun et al. 2011), both citation network datasets; a movie network dataset IMDB4k from (Fu et al. 2020); and a newspaper network dataset 20Newsgroups from (Chien et al. 2021). In DBLP4k, the hyperedges are constructed by the co-paper correlation and co-term correlation, and in IMDB4k, the hyperedges are constructed by the co-director correlation and the co-actor correlation. We refer to (Yao et al. 2024) to partition data based on labels by using the Dirichlet distribution and set β=10000𝛽10000\beta=10000 to simulate the i.i.d. setting, where number of clients is set to K=3,6,9𝐾369K=3,6,9.

Since there is no other federated hypergraph learning method applicable, we compare our FedHGN algorithm—with and without HC—against non-federated training methods on hypergraph datasets: Local HGNN where there is no communication between clients, local HGNN with HC operation, and Global HGNN where a single client uses all information of the graph. We set the number of HGNN layers to N=2𝑁2N=2 and hidden features to 161616 with drop rate p=0.5𝑝0.5p=0.5. Following the settings of GCN (Kipf and Welling 2017), in the transductive node classification task, only a portion of the nodes have labels, and only a small number of samples are used for training. Therefore, we set the validation-testing ratio on each client to 20%/40%percent20percent4020\%/40\% and adjust the training ratio based on the number of nodes and label classes, as shown in Table 1. We use Adam Optimization to minimize our cross-entropy loss function with a learning rate of 0.01 (Adam optimizer).

references: The experimental results of semi-supervised node classification on four hypergraph datasets with various types are shown in Table 2. Under different datasets and client number settings, our proposed FedHGN achieves optimal node classification accuracy. Before performing HC operation, the basic version of FedHGN outperformed the independently trained local HGNN models on the clients, with an average improvement of 5.9%. The performance gap between our federated hypergraph learning algorithm and local hypergraph models demonstrates the benefits of joint training across multiple clients. Furthermore, after conducting HC operation, the basic FedHGN is further improved by 6.8%, reducing the performance drop compared to the global HGNN from an average of 10.3% to 3.5%. The performance improvement brought by the HC operation indicates the impact of cross-client information loss and the effectiveness of our pre-training operation, which can be observed from the comparison between local HGNN models with and without the HC operation.

references: As shown in Table 3, the experimental results of FedHGN for semi-supervised node classification on three simple graph datasets demonstrate its optimal performance. Before incorporating the HC operation, FedHGN did not have an advantage over other methods that ignore cross-client information loss. One potential reason is that we generate hyperedges by selecting the 1-hop neighbors from the simple graph without introducing other high-order information. However, the HC operation supplements missing cross-client information, allowing FedHGN to recover and surpass the performance of the current state-of-the-art federated subgraph learning methods. The results show that FedHGN not only addresses hypergraph mining tasks where traditional methods are not applicable but also provides a superior solution for handling cross-client information loss in federated subgraph learning.

references: By utilizing potential higher-order relationships to generate hypergraphs, FedHGN can be applied to simple graphs datasets to compare with state-of-the-art federated subgraph learning methods. we deploy the FedHGN and other algorithms on the citation network datasets Cora and CiteSeer (Sen et al. 2008), and a social network dataset Facebook (Rozemberczki, Allen, and Sarkar 2021). The details of these datasets are shown in Table 4, where the number of clients is set to K=3,8𝐾38K=3,8. The generation of hyperedges is achieved through the nearest 1-hop neighbors method on the simple graphs, as referenced in (Gao et al. 2020).
